plants.name: Chrysanthemum Ã— morifolium
plants.description: A popular garden flower known for its bright, bushy blossoms. Chrysanthemums are classic autumn bloomers in temperate regions, symbolizing longevity and joy.
plants.location: Temperate Northern Hemisphere (Europe, North America, East Asia)
plants.funFact: Chrysanthemums were first cultivated in ancient China over 2,500 years ago and are now the official flower of several countries including Japan.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub that produces large, showy, rose-like flowers in mid to late autumn. Often grown in gardens for its elegant blooms during the cooler months.
plants.location: East Asia (China, Japan, Korea) and cultivated in subtropical gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellias were named after the Jesuit botanist Georg Kamel, though he never actually described the plant.

plants.name: Poinsettia (Euphorbia pulcherrima)
plants.description: Renowned for its brilliant red and green foliage, poinsettias begin their display in autumn and are widely associated with holiday decorations.
plants.location: Native to Mexico and Central America; widely cultivated in greenhouses worldwide
plants.funFact: The bright red parts of poinsettias are actually bracts (modified leaves), not petals.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: A fast-growing Australian native tree which produces bright orange, spider-like flowers that attract birds and pollinators, typically blooming in spring and autumn.
plants.location: Eastern Australia and cultivated in warm temperate to subtropical regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Despite the name 'oak', Grevillea robusta is not related to true oaks but is a member of the protea family.
